list_definition.definition: (often with down, out etc) to reach out for and grasp, hold, lift, pull etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He took my hand
He took the book down from the shelf
He opened the drawer and took out a gun
I’ve had a tooth taken out.

list_definition.definition: (often with away, in, off, out etc) to carry, conduct or lead to another place

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: I took the books (back) to the library
He’s taking me with him
Take her into my office
The police took him away
I took the dog out for a walk
He took her out for dinner.

list_definition.definition: to do or perform some action

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: I think I’ll take a walk
Will you take a look?
He’s going to take a bath

list_definition.definition: to get, receive, buy, rent etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: I’m taking French lessons
I’ll take three kilos of strawberries
We took a house in London.

list_definition.definition: (sometimes with back) to agree to have; to accept; He took my advice; They refused to take responsibility ; I won’t take that ( insult) from you!; I’m afraid we can’t take back goods bought in a sale .
to need or require

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: How long does it take you to go home?
It takes time to do a difficult job like this.

list_definition.definition: to travel by (bus etc)

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: I’m taking the next train to London
I took a taxi.

list_definition.definition: to have enough space for

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The car takes five people.

list_definition.definition: to make a note, record etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He took a photograph of the castle
The nurse took the patient’s temperature.

list_definition.definition: to remove, use, occupy etc with or without permission

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Someone’s taken my coat
He took all my money.

list_definition.definition: to consider (as an example)

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Take John for example.

list_definition.definition: to capture or win

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He took the first prize.

list_definition.definition: (often with away, from, off) to make less or smaller by a certain amount

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Take (away) four from ten, and that leaves six.

list_definition.definition: to suppose or think (that something is the case)

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Do you take me for an idiot?

list_definition.definition: to eat or drink

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Take these pills.

list_definition.definition: to conduct, lead or run; to be in charge or control of

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Will you take the class/lecture/meeting this evening?

list_definition.definition: to consider or react or behave to (something) in a certain way

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He took the news calmly.

list_definition.definition: to feel

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He took pleasure/pride / a delight / an interest in his work.

list_definition.definition: to go down or go into (a road)

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Take the second road on the left.

list_definition.definition: the amount of money taken in a shop etc; takings

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: What was the take today?

list_definition.definition: the filming of a single scene in a cinema film

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: After five takes, the director was satisfied.

list_ex_of_english: All photographs were taken using identical camera settings.
The two players alternately take new edges, one edge per move.
Take the three-person game introduced above and suppose the players' beliefs are as specified.
An ordinary industrial robot hanging over the workcell suspended by an iron portal takes care of hexapod translocations.
The analysis was permitted to continue for 114 generations and this took approximately 24 hr in total.
As the project progresses it is the pupils that take on the responsibility for the entire process, not the teachers or leaders.
Placing and orientation of the camera for taking the pictures followed the same method as described for 38-mm photographs.
They plotted out the area and drew up plans before taking it over.
